list.expr: sum(vm_app_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(version) unless (sum(vm_app_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"} offset 20m) by(short_versionversion))
list.name: version

description: Overview for single node VictoriaMetrics v1.83.0 or higher

panels.description: How many datapoints are in storage
panels.title: Total datapoints

panels.description: Shows the datapoints ingestion rate.
panels.title: Ingestion rate

panels.description: Shows the rate of HTTP read requests.
panels.title: Read requests

panels.description: Total number of available CPUs for VM process
panels.title: Available CPU

panels.description:
Shows the number of active time series with new data points inserted during the last hour. High value may result in ingestion slowdown. 

See more details here https://docs.victoriametrics.com/FAQ.html#what-is-an-active-time-series
panels.title: Active series

panels.description: Total amount of used disk space
panels.title: Disk space usage

panels.description: Average disk usage per datapoint.
panels.title: Bytes per point

panels.description: Total size of available memory for VM process
panels.title: Available memory

panels.description: How many datapoints are inserted into storage per second
panels.title: Datapoints ingestion rate ($instance)

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the number of active time series with new data points inserted during the last hour. High value may result in ingestion slowdown. 

See following link for details:
panels.title: Active time series ($instance)

panels.description:
The less time it takes is better.
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Query duration 0.99 quantile ($instance)

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests error rate ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of logging the messages by their level. Unexpected spike in rate is a good reason to check logs.
panels.title: Logging rate

panels.description:
Percentage of used RSS memory (resident).
The RSS memory shows the amount of memory recently accessed by the application. It includes anonymous memory and data from recently accessed files (aka page cache).
The application's performance will significantly degrade when memory usage is close to 100%.

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: RSS memory % usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Share for memory allocated by the process itself. When memory usage reaches 100% it will be likely OOM-killed.
Safe memory usage % considered to be below 80%

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: RSS anonymous memory % usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of open file descriptors compared to the limit set in the OS.
Reaching the limit of open files can cause various issues and must be prevented.

See how to change limits here https://medium.com/@muhammadtriwibowo/set-permanently-ulimit-n-open-files-in-ubuntu-4d61064429a
panels.title: Open FDs ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of bytes read/write from the storage layer.
panels.title: Disk writes/reads ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of read/write syscalls such as read, pread, write, pwrite.
panels.title: Disk write/read calls ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the rate and total number of new series created over last 24h.

High churn rate tightly connected with database performance and may result in unexpected OOM's or slow queries. It is recommended to always keep an eye on this metric to avoid unexpected cardinality "explosions".

The higher churn rate is, the more resources required to handle it. Consider to keep the churn rate as low as possible.

Good references to read:
* https://www.robustperception.io/cardinality-is-key
* https://www.robustperception.io/using-tsdb-analyze-to-investigate-churn-and-cardinality
panels.title: Churn rate ($instance)

panels.description:
The percentage of slow inserts comparing to total insertion rate during the last 5 minutes. 

The less value is better. If percentage remains high (>10%) during extended periods of time, then it is likely more RAM is needed for optimal handling of the current number of active time series. 

In general, VictoriaMetrics requires ~1KB or RAM per active time series, so it should be easy calculating the required amounts of RAM for the current workload according to capacity planning docs. But the resulting number may be far from the real number because the required amounts of memory depends on many other factors such as the number of labels per time series and the length of label values. See also https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/issues/3976#issuecomment-1476883183
panels.title: Slow inserts ($instance)

panels.description: Merge assist happens when storage can't keep up with merging parts. This is usually a sign of overload for storage.
panels.title: Assisted merges ($instance)

panels.description: Slow queries rate according to `search.logSlowQueryDuration` flag, which is `5s` by default.
panels.title: Slow queries rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of used cache size from the allowed size by type. 
Values close to 100% show the maximum potential utilization.
Values close to 0% show that cache is underutilized.
panels.title: Cache usage % by type ($instance)

panels.description: Shows cache miss ratio. Lower is better.
panels.title: Cache miss ratio ($instance)

targets.expr: sum(flag{is_set="true", job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance, name, value)

panels.description:
VictoriaMetrics limits the number of labels per each metric with `-maxLabelsPerTimeseries` command-line flag.

This prevents from ingesting metrics with too many labels. The value of `maxLabelsPerTimeseries` must be adjusted for your workload.

When limit is exceeded (graph is > 0) - extra labels are dropped, which could result in unexpected identical time series.
panels.title: Labels limit exceeded ($instance)

panels.description: How many datapoints are inserted into storage per second
panels.title: Datapoints ingestion rate ($instance)
Storage full ETA ($instance)

panels.description: Shows amount of on-disk space occupied by data points and the remaining disk space at `-storageDataPath`
panels.title: Disk space usage - datapoints ($instance)

panels.description: How many datapoints are in RAM queue waiting to be written into storage. The number of pending data points should be in the range from 0 to `2*<ingestion_rate>`, since VictoriaMetrics pushes pending data to persistent storage every second.
panels.title: Pending datapoints ($instance)

panels.description: Shows how many datapoints are in the storage and what is average disk usage per datapoint.
panels.title: Datapoints ($instance)

panels.description:
Data parts of LSM tree.
High number of parts could be an evidence of slow merge performance - check the resource utilization.
* `indexdb` - inverted index
* `storage/small` - recently added parts of data ingested into storage(hot data)
* `storage/big` -  small parts gradually merged into big parts (cold data)
panels.title: LSM parts ($instance)

panels.description: Shows how many rows were ignored on insertion due to corrupted or out of retention timestamps.
panels.title: Rows ignored for last 1h ($instance)

panels.description: The number of on-going merges in storage nodes.  It is expected to have high numbers for `storage/small` metric.
panels.title: Active merges ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows how many ongoing insertions (not API /write calls) on disk are taking place, where:
* `max` - equal to number of CPUs;
* `current` - current number of goroutines busy with inserting rows into underlying storage.

Every successful API /write call results into flush on disk. However, these two actions are separated and controlled via different concurrency limiters. The `max` on this panel can't be changed and always equal to number of CPUs. 

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means storage is overloaded and requires more CPU.
panels.title: Concurrent flushes on disk ($instance)

panels.description: The number of rows merged per second by storage nodes.
panels.title: Merge speed ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of number of series read per query.
panels.title: Series read per query ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of number of raw samples read per queried series.
panels.title: Datapoints read per series ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of number of raw datapoints read per query.
panels.title: Datapoints read per query ($instance)

panels.description:
99th percentile of number of raw samples scanner per query.

This number can exceed number of RowsReadPerQuery if `step` query arg passed to [/api/v1/query_range](https://prometheus.io/docs/prometheus/latest/querying/api/#range-queries) is smaller than the lookbehind window set in square brackets of [rollup function](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/MetricsQL.html#rollup-functions). For example, if `increase(some_metric[1h])` is executed with the `step=5m`, then the same raw samples on a hour time range are scanned `1h/5m=12` times. See [this article](https://valyala.medium.com/how-to-optimize-promql-and-metricsql-queries-85a1b75bf986) for details.
panels.title: Datapoints scanned per query ($instance)

title: VictoriaMetrics
